Of all the strands of U.S. trade and sanctions policy against China, perhaps least appreciated by markets is the potential for significant investment restrictions AND export controls to be recommended by Treasury by the end of next week (June 30), and implemented soon thereafter by President Trump. This opens a major new front in the U.S.-China conflict, adding fuel to the ongoing trade war with potentially wide ranging effects on financing markets.

We have in recent weeks highlighted that a major escalatory element of the new investment measure would be the use of IEEPA (International Emergency Economic Powers Act). This is a law from 1977 that grants the President broad powers to block transactions and freeze assets of a foreign source, provided the law is invoked with the President declaring the existence of an "unusual and extraordinary threat... to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States" that originates "in whole or substantial part outside the United States”. This has been used in the past against countries like Iran, Syria, South Sudan, and North Korea, and against individuals, but it has never been used to address unfair trade practices. As with the 232 tariffs on steel/aluminum (and autos coming), the Administration has advanced an extraordinarily broad interpretation of the national security threat to justify trade actions, and while the use of IEEPA against Chinese investment is likely to be challenged, courts have generally been deferential to presidential power in this area.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

What options are we looking at? We expect - at a minimum - Treasury will target sectors where the Chinese require U.S. investors to create joint ventures with Chinese partners and allow the transfer of technology. This idea of reciprocity, as a leverage for concessions from the Chinese, would be the least aggressive option and likely command bipartisan support. Beyond this narrow list, we would expect, based on comments by Peter Navarro and other Presidential advisers, recommendations would extend to investment restrictions in "Made in China 2025" sectors such as robotics, AI, aerospace, biomedicine, and hybrid vehicles that are not already covered by joint-venture rules. Increasingly though, there are suggestions that Treasury will include a far more aggressive option or options, aimed at broad-based oversight over large swaths of Chinese investment into the United States. In this scenario, the Administration would identify a broad national security threat from Chinese direct investment, going beyond direct high tech investments to defense, manufacturing and other sectors that involve significant technologies or affects the critical industries. State involvement, through enterprises subject to state control or sovereign wealth funds, would be the basis for an intensified review.

Bottom Line: markets can at least digest tariffs and model their impacts for companies and markets. Export controls and investment restrictions represent a possible exogenous shock to global trade flows that are incredibly challenging to predict second and third level impacts. We expect these recommendations by week's end and their implementation by mid-July, if not sooner. At the ultimate hedge, perhaps this never comes to pass and this is all just posturing toward the world's greatest Art of the Deal. We hope that is the case, though all the evidence - from previous 301 deadlines to Presidential statement delivered via Tweet over the weekend - would suggest that this latest deadline will be met and it will be met with more bite than bark.
